awd_titl_txt: Operando Electron Microscopy of Nanoparticle Surfaces and Interfaces During Catalysis
awd_abstract_narration:
The project advances transmission electron microscopy as a tool for elucidating the structure of supported metal catalysts under reaction conditions.  Catalysts consisting of metal nanoparticles on oxide supports often undergo changes in structure and composition in reactive gas environments that are difficult to infer using indirect methods, thus relegating catalyst design to trial-and-error approaches.  The project will exploit new developments in the field of in situ aberration corrected transmission electron microscopy, which allows catalytic conversions to be measured simultaneously with atomic resolution observations of catalyst structure, thereby opening the door to the design of more efficient catalysts for a broad range of commercially important catalytic processes.

A catalyst sample holder has been developed that allows high-resolution electron microscopy to be conducted in the presence of flowing gas mixtures of the types used in commercially important reactions, especially those relevant to low-temperature hydrogen fuel cells.  The simultaneous measurement of gas composition (via both a residual gas analyzer and electron energy loss measurements in the microscope) and associated imaging of catalyst structures, under both reactive and non-reactive conditions, will allow the construction of a database of catalyst images that can be related to catalyst activity.  Emphasis will be placed on reactions such as CO oxidation, water-gas shift, and CO preferential oxidation on Cu or Pt nanoparticles supported on cerium dioxide.  Those systems are believed to involve concerted reactions at the nanoparticle-support interface; hence, special attention will be directed to obtaining images of the structural motifs associated with the interfacial regions.  For comparison, corresponding experiments will be run on the same metal particles loaded on non-interactive supports.  It is anticipated that the database of images will provide valuable information to guide the development of more accurate models of catalyst structures under working catalyst conditions, improved computational models of catalytic sites and associated reaction mechanisms, and information needed to predict more active metal-support combinations.  The project will also involve a comprehensive set of educational and outreach efforts designed to excite students at all levels in scientific opportunities associated with electron microscopy.

por.por_cntn:
Heterogeneous catalysis is an important approach to regulate and control chemical reactions in which an initial set of reactant molecules is converted into a final set of product molecules. It is estimated that 90% of all manufactured products involve catalytic processes somewhere in their production chain, and such products have considerable impact in energy generation and storage, healthcare (pharmaceuticals), agriculture, transportation, and the environment. Nanoparticle surfaces often serve as catalysts since they are able to regulate surface chemistry by opening up desirable reaction pathways and shutting down undesirable pathways. A catalytic process is cyclic and in applications, the same nanoparticle surface can convert reactant molecules into product molecules thousands or millions of times. In a real catalyst, a nanoparticle of one material is often supported on a nanoparticle of a second material and the interaction between the two nanomaterials may be critical to the catalytic functionality. A high magnification electron microscope image of a platinum (Pt) nanoparticles sitting on a cerium oxide (CeO2) support is shown in Figure 1 and individual atomic columns can be seen.  

The fundamental processes taking place on the surface of a nanoparticle catalyst are complex and not well understood but typically involve capture of reactant molecules, chemical bond making/breaking, re-arrangement of molecular fragments, and finally, the formation and release of product molecules. The bond making and breaking that takes place may also cause the atoms in the nanoparticle surface to be dynamic and move. A key question for the current project was to determine if this atom dynamics really occurs during catalysis. The answer to this question would then improve our fundamental understanding of catalytic processes.

To test this hypothesis, we conducted catalysis experiments inside an electron microscope. The high spatial resolution available in modern electron microscopes allows us to directly see the atoms in the catalytic nanoparticle. The specialized electron microscope employed contains a small chemical reactor so that the atoms can be observed during a catalytic reaction.

Several reactions relevant to energy and the environment were investigated. Figure 2 shows an image of a catalyst consisting of Pt particles on a CeO2 support under conditions relevant to the catalytic conversion of carbon monoxide to carbon dioxide. The left-hand panel was recorded in the presence of oxygen and carbon monoxide gas but at a temperature where no catalysis takes place. (This image is very similar to Figure 1 but, the Pt atomic columns are now black due to the microscope setting). The image on the right was recorded at a higher temperature where catalysis takes place (28% of the carbon monoxide was converted to carbon dioxide i.e. conversion, X = 28%) and shows that atomic dynamics is occurring. Specifically, the atoms on the surface of the CeO2 (circled in red) show horizontal streaking.  This streaking is caused by rapid motion of the atoms and is similar to the streaking that would be present in a photograph of a fast-moving car. The rapid motion of the Ce atoms is associated with oxygen transport from the solid surface to the gas molecules during catalysis. The atomic columns in the Pt nanoparticle are also very difficult to clearly resolve when catalysis is taking place because of rapid motion of the Pt atoms. In this case, the Pt nanoparticle partially detaches from the CeO2 support resulting in complete structural destabilization. Figure 2 thus proves our hypothesis that, at least for the chemical reactions investigated in this study, the atoms on the catalyst surface are highly dynamic during catalysis. Future research will focus on more detailed investigations of the exact nature of the atomic motion and how it facilitates the surface chemical reactions.  Increasing our fundamental understanding of catalytic systems will have a potentially large impact on society since it will pave the way to developed improved catalytic nanomaterials.

This project provided educational opportunities for graduate and undergraduate students from diverse backgrounds and underrepresented groups to learn about modern catalytic science, nanomaterials and advanced electron microscopy methods. Aspects of this project were integrated into ASU?s engineering educational outreach activities targeting urban and rural K-12 students. The graduate student involved in this project, Joshua Vincent, was also engaged in professional development activities to enhance his communication and leadership skills. Joshua played a key role in launching ASU?s Chemical Engineering Graduate Student Club. He also served in a leadership role in the Microscopy Society of America by organizing and running a pre-meeting congress on Electron Microscopy in Liquids and Gases in 2020.
